etymaramaic.etymaramaicbefore: For Syr and T the protoform can be reconstructed as *ˀattaṯā (with a subsequent metathesis in T), while the forms attested in other Aramaic idioms, both ancient and modern, point to i in the first syllable, i.e., *ˀittaṯā. For the plural there are also two main possibilities: *niššīn (Syr, CPA, T) and *nVšīn (*našīn?), cf. nəšīn in JPA, JBA, TO. In NENA (CU, B, JNA, JNAB) Arm *ˀittaṯā was ousted by a new term baxta with unclear etymology [DCU 101, DNAB 1243, JNAD 110, DB 337]. While Mutzafi [DB 337] suggests a back-formation from bāḵtāṯā ‘female spinners’, cf. Syr ܒܟܟܬܐ , CAL proposes a semantic shift from a term for “hen”, cf. Syr ܒܟܬܐ .

For the plural there are also two main possibilities: *niššīn (Syr, CPA, T) and *nVšīn (*našīn?), cf. nəšīn in JPA, JBA, TO. In NENA (CU, B, JNA, JNAB) Arm *ˀittaṯā was ousted by a new term baxta with unclear etymology [DCU 101, DNAB 1243, JNAD 110, DB 337]. While Mutzafi [DB 337] suggests a back-formation from bāḵtāṯā ‘female spinners’, cf. Syr ܒܟܟܬܐ , CAL proposes a semantic shift from a term for “hen”, cf. Syr ܒܟܬܐ .

translationcontents.translationcontent: Guʿal, daughter of Barʿata, wife of Seluk
